block.p: The British pop star Sting received the most nominations -- six -- for the 36th annual Grammy Awards. He will compete with the singer and songwriter Billy Joel for record, album and song of the year. The winners will be announced on March 1 in a CBS telecast from Radio City Music Hall.
More than 400 nominations in 81 categories were announced yesterday by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences at a news conference at the Apollo Theater in Manhattan.

The British pop star Sting received the most nominations -- six -- for the 36th annual Grammy Awards. He will compete with the singer and songwriter Billy Joel for record, album and song of the year. The winners will be announced on March 1 in a CBS telecast from Radio City Music Hall.
More than 400 nominations in 81 categories were announced yesterday by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences at a news conference at the Apollo Theater in Manhattan.

Sting's "If I Ever Lose My Faith in You" and Mr. Joel's "River of Dreams" were both nominated as record of the year (an award given to a single) and as song of the year (a songwriters' award). The albums that include the songs were nominated in the album category.

Sting and Mr. Joel, who received four nominations, will also compete in the category of best pop vocal performance by a man. Others with several nominations include the composer Alan Menken and the producer David Foster, with five each, and the alternative rock band R.E.M. and the pop singer Whitney Houston, with four each.
The awards are decided by 7,000 members of the recording academy, who are singers, musicians and record-business professionals. Recordings released from Oct. 1, 1992 to Sept. 30, 1993 were eligible.
